1.C SubspacesDefinition Sums of Subspaces
Definition3sum of subsets
Suppose U1,⋯,UmU1,⋯,Um are subsets of V.V. The sum of U1,⋯UmU1,⋯Um , denoted U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um, is the set of all possible sums of elements of U1,⋯,UmU1,⋯,Um. More precisely,U1+⋯+Um:={u1+⋯+um:u1∈U1,⋯,um∈Um}U1+⋯+Um:={u1+⋯+um:u1∈U1,⋯,um∈Um}
Example3.1
Suppose UU is the set of all elements of F3F3 whose second and third coordinates equal 0, and WW is the set of all elements of F3F3 whose first and third coordinates equal 0:U={(x, 0, 0)∈F3:x∈F} and W={(0, y, 0)∈F3:y∈F}U={(x,0,0)∈F3:x∈F}andW={(0,y,0)∈F3:y∈F}ThenU+W={(x,y,0)∈F3: x,y∈F}U+W={(x,y,0)∈F3:x,y∈F}
Theorem4Sum of subspaces is the smallest containing subspace
Suppose U1,⋯UmU1,⋯Um are subspaces of VV. Then U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um is the smallest subspace of VV containing U1,⋯,UmU1,⋯,Um.Proof : • First it's easy to prove U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um is a subspace of V. • Then, every subspace in U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um containing U1,⋯,UmU1,⋯,Um must contain U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um because subspaces must contain all finite sums of their elements (closed under addition), so if it contains U1U1 and U2U2, then the element of U1+U2U1+U2 must be contained to.
 Now, what about the situation each vector in U1+⋯UmU1+⋯Um can be represented in the from above in only one way?
Definition5Direct Sum
Suppose U1,⋯UmU1,⋯Um are subspaces of VV. • Then U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um is called a direct sum if each element of U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um can be written in only one way as a sum u1+⋯umu1+⋯um, where each ujuj is in UjUj• If U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um is a direct sum, then U1⊕⋯⊕UnU1⊕⋯⊕Un denotes U1+⋯UmU1+⋯Um, with the ⊕⊕ notation serving as an indication that this is a direct sum.
Example5.1direct sum
Suppose UU is the subspace of F3F3 of those vectors whose last coordinates equal 0, and WW is the subspace of F3F3 of those vectors whose first two coordinates equal 0:U={(x,y,0)∈F3:x,y∈F} and W={(0,0,z)∈F3: z∈F}.U={(x,y,0)∈F3:x,y∈F}andW={(0,0,z)∈F3:z∈F}.The F3=U⊕WF3=U⊕W.
 The definition of direct sum requires that every vector in the sum have a unique representation as an appropriate sum. The next result shows that when deciding whether a sum is direct, you only need consider whether 0 can be uniquely written as an appropriate sum.
Theorem6The condition of direct sum
Suppose U1,⋯UmU1,⋯Um are subspaces of VV. Then U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um is a direct sum if and only if the only way to write 00 as a sum u1+⋯+umu1+⋯+um, where each ujuj is in UjUj, is by taking each ujuj equal to 00.Proof • First suppose U1+⋯+UmU1+⋯+Um is a direct sum. Then the definition requires 0 can only be represented by one way. Then because each UjUj is a subspace of UU, so it means 0∈Uj0∈Uj, thus 0+⋯+0=00+⋯+0=0 is possible. So the only way to write 0 as a sum is it.• If we can write 0 in the only way, then we can't write a vector in two ways:v=u1+⋯um=𝜈1+⋯𝜈mv=u1+⋯um=𝜈1+⋯𝜈m• Subtracting these two equations, we have0=(u1-𝜈1)+⋯(um-𝜈m)0=(u1-𝜈1)+⋯(um-𝜈m)• Because 0=0+⋯+00=0+⋯+0, sou1=𝜈1, u2=𝜈2,⋯□u1=𝜈1,u2=𝜈2,⋯
 The next result gives a simple condition for testing which pairs of subspaces give a direct sum.
Theorem7Direct sum of two subspaces
Suppose UU and WW are subspaces of VV. Then U+WU+W is a direct sum if and only if U∩W={0}U∩W={0}Proof If it's a direct sum, then, there can't be other representation of 0 except 0+00+0. If U∩W={0,s}U∩W={0,s}, then because of the addition conservation, there must be a -s-s in WW as well. So there can be another way to represent:0=s+(-s)0=s+(-s) Besides, it's easy to prove that if U∩W={0}U∩W={0}, there is only one way to represent 0. Thus Theorem "Condition of direct sum" is satisfied.□
More information
The results above only deals with the case of two subspaces. When asking about a possible direct sum with more than two subspaces, it is not enough to test whether U1∩U2=U1∩U3=U2∩U3={0}U1∩U2=U1∩U3=U2∩U3={0}
 Chapter2. Finite-Dimensional Vector Space2.A Span and Linear IndependenceTo avoid confusion, we will usually write lists of vectors without surrounding parentheses. For example: (4,1,6), (9,5,7) is a list of length 2 of vectors in R3R3Linear Combinations and SpanAdding up scalar multiples of vectors in a list gives what is called a linear combination of the list:
Definition8Linear Combination
A linear combination of a list v1,⋯vmv1,⋯vm of vectors in VV is a vector of the forma1v1+⋯+amvma1v1+⋯+amvmwhere a1,⋯,am∈Fa1,⋯,am∈F.
Definition9Span
 (Some mathematicians also call it linear span)
The set of all linear combination of a list of vectors v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm in VV is called the span of v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm, denoted span(v1,⋯,vm)span(v1,⋯,vm). In other wordsspan(v1,⋯,vm)={a1v1+⋯+amvm:a1,⋯,am∈F}span(v1,⋯,vm)={a1v1+⋯+amvm:a1,⋯,am∈F}The span of the empty list ( ) is defined to be {0}. Besides, we introduce a verb spans. We say that v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm spans VV.
Theorem10Span is the smallest containing subspace
Proof First we show that span(v1,⋯vm)span(v1,⋯vm) is a subspace of VV. • The additive identity is in it: set all ai=0ai=0 in equ (1). • It's closed under addition• It's closed under scalar multiplicationThen we show that spanspan is the smallest subspace• Each vjvj is a linear combination of v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm, thus is in the span.• Conversely, if we need to contain all vectors in the list, we must allow the addition and scalar multiplication. Thus we must include the span if we want to include all the vectors in the list□
 Now we can make one of the key definition in linear algebra!!!
Definition11finite-dimensional vector space
A vector space is called finite-dimensional if some list of vectors in it spans the space.
Recall that by definition every list has finite length.
Definition12polynomial, P(F)P(F)
• A function p:F→Fp:F→F is called a polynomial with coefficients in FF if there exist a0,⋯,am∈Fa0,⋯,am∈F such thatp(z)=a0+a1z+a2z2+⋯+amzmp(z)=a0+a1z+a2z2+⋯+amzm• for all z∈Fz∈F.• P(F)P(F) is the set of all polynomial with coefficients in FF.
 With the usual operations of addition and scalar multiplication, P(F)P(F) is a vector space over FF. In other words, P(F)P(F) is a subspace of FFFF, the vector space of functions from FF to FF. If a polynomial is represented by two sets of coefficients, then subtracting one representation of the polynomial from the other produces a polynomial that is identically zero as a function on FF and hence has all zero coefficients. Conclusion: the coefficients of a polynomial are uniquely determined by the polynomial.
Definition13degree of a polynomial: deg pdegp
A polynomial is said to have a degree mm if there exist am≠0am≠0 such thatp(z)=a0+a1z+⋯amzmp(z)=a0+a1z+⋯amzmfor all z∈Fz∈F. If pp has degree mm, we write deg p=mdegp=m. ★ The polynomial that is identically 0 is called to have degree -∞-∞
In next definition, we use the convention that -∞<m-∞<m, which means that the polynomial 00 is in any set of polynomials Pm(F)Pm(F).
Definition14Pm(F)Pm(F)
For mm a non-negative integer, Pm(F)Pm(F) denotes the set of all polynomials with coefficients in FF and degree at most mm.
Example14.1Pm(F)Pm(F) is a finite-dimensional vector space.
Pm(F)Pm(F) is a finite-dimensional vector space for each non-negative integer mm. Note that Pm(F)=span(1,z,⋯,zm)Pm(F)=span(1,z,⋯,zm); here we are slightly abusing notation by letting zkzk denote a function, so zm∈FFzm∈FF, and with all the number smaller than mm, they spans a bigger subspace Pm(F)Pm(F) in the vector space FFFF.
However, P(F)P(F) is infinite-dimensional!
Example14.2P(F)P(F) is an infinite-dimensional vector space.
Consider any list of elements in P(F)P(F), let mm denotes the highest degree in the list. Then the span of the list cannot represent zm+1zm+1
 Linear IndependenceSuppose v1,⋯,vm∈Vv1,⋯,vm∈V and v∈span(v1,⋯,vm)v∈span(v1,⋯,vm). If 0∈span(vj)0∈span(vj) can only be written as the combination of vjvj in one trivial way——0v1+0v2+⋯0v1+0v2+⋯, then this situation is so important that we give it a special name -- linear independence
Definition15Linearly Independence
A list v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm of vectors in V Vis called linearly independent if the only choice of a1,...,am∈Fa1,...,am∈F that makes a1v1+⋯+amvma1v1+⋯+amvm equal 0 is a1=⋯=am=0a1=⋯=am=0. ★ The empty list ( ) is also declared to be linearly independent.
 The reasoning above shows that v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm is linearly independent if and only if each vector in span(v1,⋯,vm)span(v1,⋯,vm) has only one representation as a linear combination of vjvj Now we define Linear Dependent
Definition16Linearly dependent
A list v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm of vectors in V Vis called linearly dependent if it is not linearly independent.
 In other words, a list of vector is linearly dependent if there exist a1,⋯,am∈Fa1,⋯,am∈F, not all 0, such that a1v1+⋯amvm=0a1v1+⋯amvm=0
Lemma16.1Linear Dependence Lemma
Suppose v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm is a linearly dependent list in VV . Then there exists j∈{1,2,⋯,m}j∈{1,2,⋯,m} such that the following hold:★ vj∈span(v1,⋯,vj-1)vj∈span(v1,⋯,vj-1)★ if the jthjth term is removed from v1,⋯,vmv1,⋯,vm, the span of the remaining list equals previous span.The proof is easy. Just change the form of the 0=a1v1+⋯+amvm0=a1v1+⋯+amvm, and then use other vector in the list to present any of the vjvj
The second lemma above is very useful. It means most time, we can simply add any vector into the list and remove another:
Theorem17Length of linearly independent list ⩽⩽ length of spanning list
Proof Let the vector in the linearly independent list denoted by ujuj, those in the spanning list denoted by wjwj, up to wnwn. And we do the following steps:(1) Each time, we add a new ujuj into the spanning list, thus we change it into a linear dependent list(2) Then, we remove any wjwj of the list. Because ujuj is independent.Then we create a spanning list of length nn, any other ujuj cannot be linearly independent with this spanning list.□
 We can use these theorem to prove some "trivial" true:
Theorem18Finite-dimensional subspaces
Every subspaces of a finite-dimensional vector space is finite-dimensionalProof Let v0=0v0=0. If U=span(v1,⋯,vj-1)U=span(v1,⋯,vj-1), then UU is finite-dimensional. Otherwise, choose a vector vj∈Uvj∈U such thatvj∉span(v1,⋯,vj-1)vj∉span(v1,⋯,vj-1)After each step, as long as the process continues, we have constructed a list of vectors such that no vector in this list is in the span of the previous vectors. Thus after each step, the list is linearly independent. By linear independent Lemma, This linearly independent list cannot be longer than any spanning list of VV. □
 2.B BasesIn the last section, we discussed linearly independent lists and spanning lists. Now we bring there concepts together.
Definition19basis
A basis of VV is a list of vectors in VV that is linearly independent and spans VV.
Theorem20Criterion for basis
A list v1,⋯vnv1,⋯vn of vectors in VV is a basis of V V if and only if every v∈Vv∈V can be written uniquely in the formv=a1v1+⋯+anvnv=a1v1+⋯+anvnwhere a1,⋯,an∈Fa1,⋯,an∈F.
Theorem21spanning list contains a basis
Proof ★ If spanning list is linearly independent, it's a basis★ Otherwise, remove any vector of it until it's linearly independent. □
Theorem22Basis of finite-dimensional vector space
Any finite-dimensional vector space has a basis, because it has some list spanning it.
 Our next theorem is in some sense a dual of Theorem "spanning list contains a basis"
Theorem23Linearly independent list extends to a basis
Every linearly independent list of vectors in a finite-dimensional vector space can be extended to a basis of the vector space.Proof Keep adding additional linearly independent vector into the list, until its length equal to the basis of the space. ——not formal We can simply add the basis to the independent list, keep removing vectors of it until it becomes a basis. ( Because the vector in previous list v1⋯vnv1⋯vn is linearly independent, so we don't need to remove any vjvj)
 As an application of the results above, we now show that every subspace of a finite-dimensional vector space can be paired with another subspace to form a direct sum of the whole space
Theorem24Every subspace of VV is part of sum equal to VV
A list v1,⋯vnv1,⋯vn of vectors in VV is a basis of V V if and only if every v∈Vv∈V can be written uniquely in the formv=a1v1+⋯+anvnv=a1v1+⋯+anvnwhere a1,⋯,an∈Fa1,⋯,an∈F.
2.C DimensionAlthough we have been discussing finite-dimensional vector space, what's the dimension of such an object? A reasonable definition should force the dimension of FnFn to equal nn. Notice that the standard basis(1,0,⋯,0),⋯(1,0,⋯,0),⋯of FnFn has length nn. Thus we try to define the dimension as the length of a basis. However, before doing this, can we promise that every basis of a vector space has equal length?
Theorem25Basis length does not depend on basis
ProofSuppose VV is finite-dimensional. Let B1B1 and B2B2 be two bases. Then B1B1 is a linearly independent list in the view of B2B2. The length of B2B2 thus must bigger than length of B1B1. And vice versa.
 Now we can formally define the dimension of such spaces:
Definition26dimension, dim VdimV
The dimension of a finite-dimensional vector space is the length of any basis of the vector space.
Example26.1dim Pm(F)=m+1dimPm(F)=m+1
A polynomial has dimension: dim Pm(F)=m+1dimPm(F)=m+1,because the basis is1,z,⋯zm1,z,⋯zm
 To check that a list of vectors in VV is a basis of VV , we must, according to the definition, show that the list in question satisfies two properties. However, sometimes it's easier than this:
Theorem27Linearly independent list of right length is a basis
ProofSuppose dim V=ndimV=n and v1,⋯,vnv1,⋯,vn is linearly independent in VV. The list v1,⋯,vnv1,⋯,vn can be extended to the basis, but basis has length equal nn, thus the list itself is already a basis.
Example27.1Show that list (5,7), (4,3)(5,7),(4,3) is a basis of F2F2
It's easy to show. Just remember that two vector with "," is a list.
 Similarly, we have
Theorem28Spanning list of right length is a basis
ProofSpanning list contains a basis. But all bases have the same length. Thus the list itself is a basis.
 The next result gives a formula for the dimension of the sum of two subspaces of a finite-dimensional vector space. The formula is analogous to a familiar counting formula: the number of elements in the union of two set equals the number of elements in the first set, plus the number of elements in the second set , minus the number of element in the intersection of the two set.
Theorem29Dimension of a sum
If U1U1 and U2U2 are subspaces of a finite-dimensional vector space, thendim(U1+U2)=dim U1+dim U2-dim(U1∩U2).dim(U1+U2)=dimU1+dimU2-dim(U1∩U2).ProofLet u1,⋯,umu1,⋯,um be the basis of U1∩U2U1∩U2, because u1,⋯,umu1,⋯,um are linear independent vectors in U1U1 and U2U2, we extend them to basis of UiUi. For example, u1,⋯,um,v1,⋯vnu1,⋯,um,v1,⋯vn is a basis of U1U1, u1,⋯,um,w1,⋯wku1,⋯,um,w1,⋯wk is a basis of U2U2. Now we will prove that u1,⋯,um,v1,⋯,vn,w1,⋯,wku1,⋯,um,v1,⋯,vn,w1,⋯,wk is a basis of U1+U2U1+U2.★ First, it's easy to show that u1,⋯,um,v1,⋯,vn,w1,⋯,wku1,⋯,um,v1,⋯,vn,w1,⋯,wk is a spanning list.★ Then, if v1v1 is linearly dependent with u1,⋯,um,w1,⋯,wku1,⋯,um,w1,⋯,wk, we can represent v1v1 with this list. According to the addition reservation, v1v1 is a vector of U2U2. Besides, it's a vector of U1U1, so it's in the intersection U1∩U2U1∩U2, which means it should be represented by the basis list u1,⋯,umu1,⋯,um. However, we supposed that u1,⋯,um,v1,⋯vnu1,⋯,um,v1,⋯vn is a basis of U1U1, v1v1 cannot be represented by u1,⋯,umu1,⋯,um. So v1v1 must be linear independent with u1,⋯,um,w1,⋯,wku1,⋯,um,w1,⋯,wk★ So u1,⋯,um,v1,⋯,vn,w1,⋯,wku1,⋯,um,v1,⋯,vn,w1,⋯,wk is a linearly independent list□

 The existence part of the next results means we can find a linear map that takes on whatever values we wish on the vectors in a basis. The uniqueness part means that a linear map is completely determined by its values on a basis.

So actually, there is only one map.

 Range and Surjectivity
Definition39Range
For TT a function from VV to WW, the range of TT is the subset of WW consisting of those vectors that are of the form TvTv for some v∈Vv∈V:range T={Tv:v∈V}.rangeT={Tv:v∈V}.Recall that VV is called domain here.
Also called image
Theorem40The range is a subspace
ProofAddition and scalar multiplication is closed because of the definition of linear map.□
Definition41surjective
A function TT is called surjective if its range equals WW.
 Fundamental Theorem of Linear MapsThe next result is so important that it gets a dramatic name.
Theorem42Fundamental Theorem of Linear Maps
Suppose VV is finite-dimensional and T∈L(V,W)T∈L(V,W). Then range TrangeT is finite-dimensional and dim V=dim null T+dim range T.dimV=dimnullT+dimrangeT.Proof Suppose VV has a mm length basis v1,v2,⋯,vmv1,v2,⋯,vm. When it is mapped into another space, they're changed intowj=Tvjwj=TvjIt's clearly that wjwj spans range TrangeT. Thus we can remove some of the wjwj until it remains a basis of range TrangeT. Suppose we classify wjwj into two lists: w1,⋯,wkw1,⋯,wk and wk+1,⋯,wmwk+1,⋯,wm, each wjwj in the latter list is linearly dependent with the former. In other words, w1,⋯,wkw1,⋯,wk is a basis and range TrangeT has dimension kk. Now I will prove the length n=m-kn=m-k, of list wk+1,⋯,wmwk+1,⋯,wm, is the dimension of null TnullT. Supposewj=k∑iaiwi , for j⩾k+1wj=∑ikaiwi,forj⩾k+1It means Tvj=k∑iaiT(vi)Tvj=∑ikaiT(vi) as well. Thus: let uj=vj-k∑iaiviuj=vj-∑ikaivi, T(uj)=0T(uj)=0. For every vector in null spaceT(m∑i=1aivi)=0,T(∑i=1maivi)=0,use ujuj to replace vjvj for j⩾k+1j⩾k+1. There will be more terms of vivi for i⩽ki⩽k. So we collect the coefficients and writeT(k∑i=1a'ivi+m∑j=k+1uj)=0T(∑i=1kai'vi+∑j=k+1muj)=0Because the latter term naturally equals 00, k∑i=1T(a'ivi)=k∑i=1a'iwi=0∑i=1kT(a'ivi)=∑i=1ka'iwi=0So a'i=0a'i=0. Therefore, for every vector in null space , we can use list ujuj to represent it, which means list ujuj is a span. Besides, it can be proved that ujuj is linearly independent——So the dimension of null space is n=m-kn=m-k!□
 Now we can show that no linear map from a finite-dimensional space to a "smaller" space is injective, where "smaller" is measured by dimension
Theorem43A map to a smaller dimensional space is not injective
ProofUse fundamental theorem of linear maps
Theorem44A map to a larger dimensional space is not surjective
ProofSimilarly
 The term "homogeneous" below means that all the constant value on the right of the equation system equal 0.
Example44.1Rephrase in terms of a linear map the question of whether a homogeneous system of linear equations has a nonzero solution
The equationT(x1,⋯,xn)=0T(x1,⋯,xn)=0means that x1,⋯,xnx1,⋯,xn is in the null space. Thus after rephrasing, the question becomes:Whether the linear map is injective.
Theorem45Homogeneous system of linear equations
A homogeneous system of linear equation with more variable than equations has nonzero solutions.ProofMore variable means it's a mapping into smaller space. □
Example45.1Whether an inhomogeneous system of linear equations has no solutions for some choice of the constant terms
If the range has less dimension than vector space WW, then there definitely can be some situation in which the equation has no solution. So the question can be changed as:Whether the linear map is surjective?
Theorem46Inhomogeneous system of linear equations
An inhomogeneous system of linear equation with less variable than equations has no solution for some choice of the constant termsProofMore equation means it's a mapping into bigger space. □
 3.C MatricesRepresenting a Linear Map by a Matrix
Definition47Matrix of a linear map, M(T)M(T)
Suppose T∈L(V,W)T∈L(V,W) and v1,⋯,vnv1,⋯,vn is a basis of VV and w1,⋯,wmw1,⋯,wm is a basis of WW . The matrix of T T with respect to these bases is the m-by-nm-by-n matrix M(T)M(T) whose entries Aj,kAj,k are defined byTvk=A1,kw1+⋯+Am,kwmTvk=A1,kw1+⋯+Am,kwmIf the bases are not clear from the context, then the notation M(T(v1,⋯,vn), (w1,⋯,wm))M(T(v1,⋯,vn),(w1,⋯,wm)) is used.
The matrix M(T)M(T) of a linear map T∈L(V,W)T∈L(V,W) depends on the basis v1,⋯,vnv1,⋯,vn of VV and the basis w1,⋯,wmw1,⋯,wm of WW, as well as on TT. However, the bases should be clear from the context, and thus they are often not included in the notation.
Definition48Notation Fm,nFm,n
For mm and nn positive integers, the set of all m-by-nm-by-n matrices with entries in FF is denoted by Fm,nFm,n.
